elements.content: The role of anions in the formation of diversified coordination polymers (CPs) of a flexible bidentate ligand (L), containing an aliphatic-aromatic spacer (p-xylyl) between amidopyridine moieties, has been explored. The reaction of L with Cd­(II) or Cu­(II) salts of NO3 –, ClO4 –, SO4 2–, and SiF6 2– resulted in the single crystals of eight CPs. The X-ray diffraction analyses of the single crystals reveal that the CPs contain 1D-zigzag (SiF6 2–), open (4,4)-network (NO3 – and SCN–), and the interpenetrated 2D-networks with (4,4)- and (6,3)-topologies and pseudodiamondoid network (SO4 2– and ClO4 –). These results clearly indicate that the presence of tetrahedral anions favored the interpenetration of the 2D- and 3D-networks. The resultant cationic CPs are explored for their dye adsorption ability based on the charge transfer interaction between the framework and ionic dye. Among all CPs, complex 8 containing a 3D-interpenetrated diamondoid network was found to show remarkable ability for the uptake of anionic dyes such as fluorescein dianion (FSD) and methyl orange (MO). The ability of 8 to selectively adsorb anionic dye was utilized for the separation of the MO from cationic dye such as methylene blue. Further, the FSD adsorbed material of 8 was shown to exhibit enhanced luminescence properties.

elements.content: Formation of open, interpenetrated coordination polymers showed dependency on the shape of anions because the cavities are hydrophilic in nature. Tetrahedral anions templated interpenetrated networks; flat or linear anions templated open networks. The material with triply interpenetrated pseudodiamondoid network exhibited a remarkable ability to separate cationic and anionic dyes. The dye adsorbed CP displayed enhanced luminescence properties.

elements.content: In recent times, the design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) have been paid much attention due to their potential applications such as gas storage, guest inclusion, separation, and luminescent properties. Crystal engineering of CPs involves the design of molecular building blocks which self-assemble via coordination bonds to construct higher dimensional networks. The combination of coordination bonds and hydrogen bonds in designing the CPs has been explored in order to increase the dimensionalities of the networks. In the design of network materials, the self-assembly process of metal and organic ligand plays a pivotal role to produce structure dependent functional materials. Such a self-assembly process not only depends on the coordination abilities of ligand and metal atom but also largely depends on anions which acts as templates and also on reaction conditions such as the solvents, presence of guest molecules, concentrations, and temperatures. Although the inorganic anions such as NO3 –, ClO4 –, SiF6 2–, and SO4 2– generally do not take part in the formation of coordination networks, they profoundly influence the M–L network geometries such that there is a better fit for those anions within the network cavities and channels. The hydrogen bonding ability, shape, and size of the anions are some of the important factors by which the networks/geometries and their packing are being influenced.

elements.content: The role of anions becomes more important if the organic ligands carry the functional groups capable of forming strong hydrogen bonds. Further, the resultant networks contain a cationic nature as these ions do not or weakly coordinate to the metal in the majority of the cases. These cationic framework materials have a potency to selectively adsorb anionic dyes which can be used for the removal of nonbiodegradable dyes from waste waters. Among the several processes of dye removal from the wastewater, such as physical, chemical, and biological approaches, the removal of dyes by physical adsorption technologies is considered as a competitive method due to its effectiveness, efficiency, and economy without chemical degradation of the dyes. Very recently a few studies have been reported where the MOFs were used to separate the organic dye molecules based on the cationic–anionic interaction. In a recent report, a cationic metal–organic framework was shown to uptake selectively anionic dye such as methyl orange (MO) from the mixture of cationic and anionic dyes.

elements.content: A large number of bis­(pyridyl) ligands have been explored with various types of spacers containing a combination of alkyl groups with secondary amides, esters, or urea. Recent studies from our group on CPs of the bis­(pyridyl) ligand containing secondary amides and phenyl or alkyl groups -(CH2) n - as a backbone revealed that CPs containing ligands with shorter spacers such as -(CH2)2- or -(CH2)4- exhibit versatility in producing 1D-chains containing cavities, open 2D-networks, chiral 2D-networks, and interpenetrated 2D-networks (both parallel and perpendicular modes), while the ligands with phenyl, hexyl, or octyl spacers have consistently formed 2D-networks which are further linked by amide-to-amide hydrogen bonds. However, not many reports on CPs of bis-pyridyl molecules containing secondary amides with aliphatic-aromatic moieties were reported to date.

elements.content: In this contribution, we present our studies on CPs of a flexible ligand (L), N-pyridin-3-yl-2-[4-(pyridin-3-ylcarbamoylmethyl)­phenyl]­acetamide, containing an aliphatic-aromatic spacer between amidopyridine moieties (). The dimensionality and open/interpenetration of the networks of CPs are found to depend on the shape and size of the anions. The shapes of the anions utilized in these studies are planar (NO3 –), tetrahedral (ClO4 – and SO4 2–), and octahedral (SiF6 2–). Accordingly, 1D-, 2D-, and 3D-networks resulted with Cd­(II) and Cu­(II) metal salts depending on the presence of anions. Further among these cationic CPs, a 3D-diamondoid network was found to exhibit excellent ability to adsorb and separate anionic dyes such as methyl orange and fluorescein via selective adsorption. The luminescence properties of CP and dye adsorbed CP have been explored, and it was found that dye adsorbed CP exhibit enhanced luminescent properties compared to their respective parent CP.

elements.content: Ligand L was synthesized following the previously reported procedure. Recently, it was shown by us that L forms a 3D-network with Cd­(OAc)2 with the inclusion of unprecedented one-dimensional water cages. The complexation reactions were carried out either by the direct mixing of the MeOH solutions (5 mL) of L (0.1 mmol, 0.0346 g) with the MeOH solution (5 mL) of the corresponding Cu­(II) or Cd­(II) salts (0.05 mmol) or by the layering procedures. The single crystals of complexes 2, 3, 4, and 8 have been synthesized via direct mixing procedure, whereas complexes 1, 5, 6, and 7 were obtained by layering the MeOH solution (5 mL) of ligand over aqueous solution of the corresponding metal salts. Although all the complexation reactions were carried out by taking the metal–ligand in 1:2 ratio, the resulting complexes were found to contain various metal–ligand compositions such as ML, ML 2, and M2 L 3. The pertinent crystallographic details for complexes 1–8 were given in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Ligand L was synthesized following the previously reported procedure. Recently, it was shown by us that L forms a 3D-network with Cd(OAc)2 with the inclusion of unprecedented one-dimensional water cages. The complexation reactions were carried out either by the direct mixing of the MeOH solutions (5 mL) of L (0.1 mmol, 0.0346 g) with the MeOH solution (5 mL) of the corresponding Cu(II) or Cd(II) salts (0.05 mmol) or by the layering procedures. The single crystals of complexes 2, 3, 4, and 8 have been synthesized via direct mixing procedure, whereas complexes 1, 5, 6, and 7 were obtained by layering the MeOH solution (5 mL) of ligand over aqueous solution of the corresponding metal salts. Although all the complexation reactions were carried out by taking the metal-ligand in 1:2 ratio, the resulting complexes were found to contain various metal-ligand compositions such as ML, ML 2, and M2 L 3. The pertinent crystallographic details for complexes 1-8 were given in .

The X-ray diffraction analyses of single crystals revealed that the networks obtained here include 1D-zigzag chain (1 and 2), open (4,4)-network (3 and 4), doubly (7) and triply (6) parallel interpenetrated networks with (4,4)-topology, 3-fold parallel interpenetrated network with (6,3)-topology (5), and 3-fold-interpenetrated pseudodiamondoid network (8). The presence of tetrahedral anions such as SO4 2– and ClO4 – have been found to template interpenetrated networks in a consistent manner, whereas the presence of other anions such as NO3 –, SCN–, and SiF6 2–, resulting in noninterpenetrated networks. The cationic diamondoid network (8) was employed in order to uptake the anionic dye from their aqueous solution. Further the solid state luminescence emission of the d10 metal system, i.e., the Cd­(II)-CPs as well as dye adsorbed CPs, was studied where the emission maximum of dye adsorbed CPs was found to be red-shifted with respect to the emission maximum of parent CPs. Geometrical parameters of hydrogen bonds for complexes 1–8 have been given in the Supporting Information.

The presence of tetrahedral anions such as SO4 2- and ClO4 - have been found to template interpenetrated networks in a consistent manner, whereas the presence of other anions such as NO3 -, SCN-, and SiF6 2-, resulting in noninterpenetrated networks. Geometrical parameters of hydrogen bonds for complexes 1-8 have been given in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The complexation reactions of L with CuSiF6 and CdSiF6 resulted in the complexes of 1 and 2. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that 1 and 2 are isostructural and crystallized in P2/n space group. The asymmetric units are composed of metal ions with half-occupancy, a half-unit each of L and SiF6 2–, and three water molecules (two coordinated and one noncoordinated). The metals exhibit octahedral coordination geometry with four water molecules in equatorial positions (Cu–O, 2.139(4), 2.191(3) Å; Cd–O, 2.279(8), 2.327(7) Å) and two pyridine moieties at axial positions (Cu–N, 2.019(3) Å; Cd–N, 2.310(7) Å). This type of coordination leads to the formation of one-dimensional-zigzag chains (a) which are joined together by a plethora of hydrogen bonds between coordinated H2O molecules and CO of amide functionalities. There exist channels in the lattice along the b-axis which are occupied by the SiF6 2– anions and free water molecules. Amide N–H groups exclusively form N–H···F hydrogen bonds with SiF6 2– anions (b,c).

elements.content: The reactions of L with nitrate and thiocynate salts of Cd­(II) resulted in the single crystals of complexes 3 and 4, respectively. elements.content: As a result it contains a corrugated 2D-layer with rectangular grids of dimensions 18 × 17.0 Å2. The layers pack on each other in an offset mode via amide-to-amide N–H···O hydrogen bonding, face-to-face and edge-to-face aromatic interactions (). Further coordinated NO3 – or SCN– ions form N–H···O and N–H···S hydrogen bonds, respectively, with one of the amide moieties. In each case due to the inherent flexibility in its backbone the coordinated L molecules exhibit two different arm lengths (13.931, 15.263 Å in 3 and 14.176, 14.879 Å in 4) which correspond to the formation of a rectangular grid.

elements.content: The presence of tetrahedral anions such as SO4 2– and ClO4 – were found to result in the interpenetrated networks in complexes 5–7. The diffusion of aqueous solution of CuSO4 into a MeOH solution of ligand L resulted in light blue colored crystals of 5 with M2 L 3 composition. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 5 crystallized in P21/n space group and the asymmetric unit is composed of one unit each of Cu­(II) and SO4 2– ions, one and a half units of L, and six water molecules, one being coordinated and five being noncoordinated. Cu­(II) exhibits a distorted square pyramidal geometry with the equatorial positions occupied by three L units (Cu–N, 2.046(7), 2.039(7), and 2.020(6) Å) and one SO4 2– ion (Cu–O, 1.971(6) Å) and water molecule (Cu–O, 2.242(7) Å) at apical position. Metal–ligand coordination produces a trigonal planar node which propagates along the plane to form a herringbone network with (6,3)-topology containing large cavities, and the cavities of the network are filled by the 3-fold parallel self-interpenetration (a,b). The L molecules of the interpenetrated layers interact with each other via C–H···O and edge-to-face aromatic interactions which are responsible for triple and parallel interpenetration of the layers by the formation of triple helices of -ML- chains (d,e). The triply interpenetrated layers are connected further by the hydrogen bonding between coordinated sulfate ions, water molecules, and amide N–H groups (f).

The presence of tetrahedral anions such as SO4 2- and ClO4 - were found to result in the interpenetrated networks in complexes 5-7. The diffusion of aqueous solution of CuSO4 into a MeOH solution of ligand L resulted in light blue colored crystals of 5 with M2 L 3 composition. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 5 crystallized in P21/n space group and the asymmetric unit is composed of one unit each of Cu(II) and SO4 2- ions, one and a half units of L, and six water molecules, one being coordinated and five being noncoordinated. Cu(II) exhibits a distorted square pyramidal geometry with the equatorial positions occupied by three L units (Cu-N, 2.046(7), 2.039(7), and 2.020(6) Å) and one SO4 2- ion (Cu-O, 1.971(6) Å) and water molecule (Cu-O, 2.242(7) Å) at apical position. Metal-ligand coordination produces a trigonal planar node which propagates along the plane to form a herringbone network with (6,3)-topology containing large cavities, and the cavities of the network are filled by the 3-fold parallel self-interpenetration (a,b). The L molecules of the interpenetrated layers interact with each other via C-H⋅⋅⋅O and edge-to-face aromatic interactions which are responsible for triple and parallel interpenetration of the layers by the formation of triple helices of -ML- chains (d,e). The triply interpenetrated layers are connected further by the hydrogen bonding between coordinated sulfate ions, water molecules, and amide N-H groups (f).

elements.content: The reactions of L with CdSO4 and Cu­(ClO4)2 resulted in the single crystals of complexes 6 and 7. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 6 crystallized in P21/n space group while 7 crystallized in P21212 chiral space group. The asymmetric unit of 6 contains two units each of L and coordinated MeOH molecules and one unit each of Cd­(II), SO4 2– and free water molecule. In 7, the asymmetric unit is composed of one unit each of L, ClO4 –, and Cu­(II) with half-occupancy and one each of coordinated and free water molecules. In both complexes metals exhibit octahedral coordination geometry with four pyridyl groups at equatorial positions (Cd–N, 2.351(5), 2.325(5), 2.343(5), and 2.334(5) Å; Cu–N, 2.028(4) and 2.026(4) Å) and two solvent molecules (MeOH in 6 and H2O in 7) at apical positions (Cd–O, 2.322(5) and 2.375(5) Å; Cu–O, 2.573(4) Å). Further, both structures contain (4,4)-layers with ML 2 composition. Interestingly, the 2D-layers differ significantly; in 6 they contain square cavities with perfect grid geometries (a) whereas in 7 they have ellipsoidal cavities with a brick wall type geometry (a). In both structures the cavities are filled by parallel self-interpenetration.

elements.content:
Complex 6 exhibits 3-fold interpenetration (b) while 7 exhibits 2-fold interpenetration (b) which lead to 2D → 2D-networks.

In 6, the parallel interpenetration of the layers occurs through weak interaction such as C–H···O hydrogen bonding and edge-to-face aromatic interactions (c). In 7, the interpenetration was assisted by the formation of β-sheet N–H···O hydrogen bonds and π–π interactions (c). Further, in 6 and 7 such interpenetration was also assisted by the formation of triple (d) and double helices (e), respectively. In both cases the anions were trapped within the interpenetrated networks by the formation of N–H···O and O–H···O hydrogen bonds. Interestingly in 7, the anions and water molecules form a 2D-hexagonal layer which interpenetrates with the 2D-coordination networks in nearly perpendicular direction (d). It is important to note here that Cu­(ClO4)2 with bis­(3-pyridylamido)­butane was shown by us to form a similar structure with the same structural formula but the space group was C2.

Complex 6 exhibits 3-fold interpenetration (b) while 7 exhibits 2-fold interpenetration (b) which lead to 2D → 2D-networks.

In 6, the parallel interpenetration of the layers occurs through weak interaction such as C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and edge-to-face aromatic interactions (c). In 7, the interpenetration was assisted by the formation of β-sheet N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds and π-π interactions (c). Further, in 6 and 7 such interpenetration was also assisted by the formation of triple (d) and double helices (e), respectively. In both cases the anions were trapped within the interpenetrated networks by the formation of N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds. Interestingly in 7, the anions and water molecules form a 2D-hexagonal layer which interpenetrates with the 2D-coordination networks in nearly perpendicular direction (d). It is important to note here that Cu(ClO4)2 with bis(3-pyridylamido)butane was shown by us to form a similar structure with the same structural formula but the space group was C2.

elements.content: Complexation reaction of L with Cd­(ClO4)2 afforded single crystals of complex 8. It crystallized in C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains Cd­(II) with half-occupancy, two half-units of L, one ClO4 –, and two water molecules (one coordinated and one free). The Cd­(II) ion adopts a distorted octahedral geometry where the equatorial positions are occupied by two pyridyl moieties of L (Cd–N, 2.380(3) Å) and two water molecules (Cd–O, 2.309(4) Å) while the axial positions are occupied by two pyridyl moieties of L (Cd–N, 2.333(3) Å). This type of coordination resulted in a distorted tetrahedral node (c) which was interconnected by L to form a three-dimensional diamondoid network (a). The 3-fold self-interpenetration of the networks and anions filled the channels of the 3D-network. The interpenetrated networks interact with each other via N–H···O hydrogen bonds and π–π aromatic interactions (d). The two symmetry independent L units differ significantly with respect to their geometries: one exhibits extended conformation with length of 16.914 Å, while the other exhibits somewhat folded conformation with a length of 13.927 Å. Due to such differences, the network contains two types of arm with metal-to-metal separation of 20.796 and 16.153 Å to result in the formation of a pseudodiamondoid network (b). It is interesting to note here that a similar network was reported by us earlier with bis­(amido-3-pyridyl)­ethane and Cu­(PF6)2; however the coordination of the Cu­(II) there differs significantly as the four pyridyl groups occupy equatorial positions. Further, we note here that a type of organic node similar to that of the CdN4 unit observed here was shown by us earlier to form a 4-fold-interpenetrated quartz network via N–H···O hydrogen bonds.

3-Fold Diamondoid Network with Octahedral Coordination Geometry of Cd(II)

Complexation reaction of L with Cd(ClO4)2 afforded single crystals of complex 8. It crystallized in C2/c space group, and the asymmetric unit contains Cd(II) with half-occupancy, two half-units of L, one ClO4 -, and two water molecules (one coordinated and one free). The Cd(II) ion adopts a distorted octahedral geometry where the equatorial positions are occupied by two pyridyl moieties of L (Cd-N, 2.380(3) Å) and two water molecules (Cd-O, 2.309(4) Å) while the axial positions are occupied by two pyridyl moieties of L (Cd-N, 2.333(3) Å). This type of coordination resulted in a distorted tetrahedral node (c) which was interconnected by L to form a three-dimensional diamondoid network (a). The 3-fold self-interpenetration of the networks and anions filled the channels of the 3D-network. The interpenetrated networks interact with each other via N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds and π-π aromatic interactions (d). The two symmetry independent L units differ significantly with respect to their geometries: one exhibits extended conformation with length of 16.914 Å, while the other exhibits somewhat folded conformation with a length of 13.927 Å. Due to such differences, the network contains two types of arm with metal-to-metal separation of 20.796 and 16.153 Å to result in the formation of a pseudodiamondoid network (b). It is interesting to note here that a similar network was reported by us earlier with bis(amido-3-pyridyl)ethane and Cu(PF6)2; however the coordination of the Cu(II) there differs significantly as the four pyridyl groups occupy equatorial positions. Further, we note here that a type of organic node similar to that of the CdN4 unit observed here was shown by us earlier to form a 4-fold-interpenetrated quartz network via N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: All the cationic CPs reported here are explored for their dye adsorption ability due to the charge transfer interaction between the framework and ionic dye. Cationic Cu­(II) complexes 1 and 7 were found to be incapable of adsorbing dye as the mixture of precipitates was being formed when the corresponding crystals were dipped in the aqueous solution of anionic dyes such as fluorescein dianion (FSD; ) or methyl orange (MO; ). Further, the XRPD of these precipitates were found to be different from that of the parent CPs. Further similar results were observed for the cationic Cd­(II) complexes 2 and 6 with the exception of 8. It can be also noted that among all the CPs reported here only 8 contains the cationic 3D-network which may be withstanding for dye adsorption compared to other lower dimensional CPs. In complex 8, the triply interpenetrated diamondoid network contains cavities that are filled with ClO4 – ions and water molecules. Therefore, complex 8 was found to show remarkable ability to adsorb anionic dyes such as FSD and MO. The absorption of FSD is an important aspect to fine-tune the luminescence properties while the absorption of MO is important as it is a toxic dye which is present in wastewater. Accordingly, complex 8 was used to adsorb FSD and MO from aqueous dye solutions. The FSD adsorbed materials of 8 were further explored for their luminescence properties. In the case of MO, the selective adsorption of MO in the presence of cationic dye such as methylene blue was explored.

Dye Adsorption and Separation

All the cationic CPs reported here are explored for their dye adsorption ability due to the charge transfer interaction between the framework and ionic dye. Cationic Cu(II) complexes 1 and 7 were found to be incapable of adsorbing dye as the mixture of precipitates was being formed when the corresponding crystals were dipped in the aqueous solution of anionic dyes such as fluorescein dianion (FSD; ) or methyl orange (MO; ). Further, the XRPD of these precipitates were found to be different from that of the parent CPs. Further similar results were observed for the cationic Cd(II) complexes 2 and 6 with the exception of 8. It can be also noted that among all the CPs reported here only 8 contains the cationic 3D-network which may be withstanding for dye adsorption compared to other lower dimensional CPs. In complex 8, the triply interpenetrated diamondoid network contains cavities that are filled with ClO4 - ions and water molecules. Therefore, complex 8 was found to show remarkable ability to adsorb anionic dyes such as FSD and MO. The absorption of FSD is an important aspect to fine-tune the luminescence properties while the absorption of MO is important as it is a toxic dye which is present in wastewater. Accordingly, complex 8 was used to adsorb FSD and MO from aqueous dye solutions. The FSD adsorbed materials of 8 were further explored for their luminescence properties. In the case of MO, the selective adsorption of MO in the presence of cationic dye such as methylene blue was explored.

elements.content: Fluorescein is regarded as one of the major xanthene dyes with a wide variety of applications due to its high absorption in the visible range and high quantum yield of fluorescence. Given the anionic nature of FSD, it is expected to interact with the cationic framework via charge transfer interactions. The emission profile of the dye adsorbed material can be fine-tuned by varying the amount of dye adsorbed in the cationic network (Supporting Information). The resultant materials have a spectrum of emission profiles which can be of great utility for electro-optic devices. In order to have the dye doped materials, the crystals of 8 (cationic framework) were immersed in aqueous solution of FSD (10 mL, 10–2 M). As the time progressed the gradual change in color of the crystals of 8 was observed, and after 24 h dye doped orange colored crystals (8a) resulted (). Although the material 8a retained its crystallinity, it was not suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction. However, the network was found to be intact by comparing powder patterns of 8 and 8a (Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption of FSD and Tuning of Emission Profile

Fluorescein is regarded as one of the major xanthene dyes with a wide variety of applications due to its high absorption in the visible range and high quantum yield of fluorescence. Given the anionic nature of FSD, it is expected to interact with the cationic framework via charge transfer interactions. The emission profile of the dye adsorbed material can be fine-tuned by varying the amount of dye adsorbed in the cationic network (Supporting Information). The resultant materials have a spectrum of emission profiles which can be of great utility for electro-optic devices. In order to have the dye doped materials, the crystals of 8 (cationic framework) were immersed in aqueous solution of FSD (10 mL, 10-2 M). As the time progressed the gradual change in color of the crystals of 8 was observed, and after 24 h dye doped orange colored crystals (8a) resulted (). Although the material 8a retained its crystallinity, it was not suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction. However, the network was found to be intact by comparing powder patterns of 8 and 8a (Supporting Information).

elements.content: The solid state luminescence properties of 8 and 8a have been investigated at room temperature. Complex 8 has exhibited a broad band emission in the violet region with a maximum at 410 nm at the excitation wavelength of 350 nm (). The solid state UV–visible spectrum of 8 shows a broad range absorption in the region 250–350 nm, and accordingly complex 8 was excited at 350 nm (Supporting Information). The material of L was found to be luminescence inactive with the excitation wavelengths of 280, 320, 350, or 380 nm indicating that the luminescence property of 8 did not originate from L. Therefore, it can be understood that these properties are originating from the interactions between Cd­(II) (d10) and the ligand L. For the sake of comparison, the luminescence profiles of Cu­(II) (d9) containing CPs (1, 5, and 7) were also recorded at various excited wavelengths, but they were found to be nonluminescent.

elements.content: Further, the solid state luminescence emission of the FSD doped 8 (8a) was investigated at room temperature with an excitation wavelength of 440 nm. Interestingly the material 8a was found to exhibit an intense emission peak at 565 nm indicating a red shift of 155 nm with respect to that of 8 (). It is important to note here that the FSD was found to exhibit a broad low intense emission in the yellow region with a maximum at 590 nm with excitation at 440 nm. The emission maximum of 8a is in the green region which is in between the emission maximum of 8 (in the violet region) and FSD (in the yellow region). This type of intermediate emission was observed by us previously, and the possible reason may be the charge transfer interaction between the cationic framework of the d10 metal and anionic dye molecules.

Interestingly the material 8a was found to exhibit an intense emission peak at 565 nm indicating a red shift of 155 nm with respect to that of 8 (). It is important to note here that the FSD was found to exhibit a broad low intense emission in the yellow region with a maximum at 590 nm with excitation at 440 nm. The emission maximum of 8a is in the green region which is in between the emission maximum of 8 (in the violet region) and FSD (in the yellow region). This type of intermediate emission was observed by us previously, and the possible reason may be the charge transfer interaction between the cationic framework of the d10 metal and anionic dye molecules.

elements.content: MO is a water-soluble anionic azo dye, which is being widely used in textile, printing, paper, food, and pharmaceutical industries, and also in research laboratories. The removal of dyes from wastewater by physical adsorption is the prominent method compared to other methodologies. In a typical dye sorption experiment, the crystals of 8 (10 mg) were immersed in the aqueous solution of MO (0.1 mmol L–1) and kept in the dark. Within a short time, the light orange colored solution turned to colorless, while the colorless crystals turned to yellow. The change in the concentration of MO in the aqueous solution was monitored by UV–visible spectroscopy at various time intervals after immersing the crystals of 8 (). We note here that no further activation was needed for 8 to uptake MO compared to some of the previously reported CP-based materials.
elements.clean_text:
Selective Separation of Anionic Toxic Dyes

MO is a water-soluble anionic azo dye, which is being widely used in textile, printing, paper, food, and pharmaceutical industries, and also in research laboratories. The removal of dyes from wastewater by physical adsorption is the prominent method compared to other methodologies. In a typical dye sorption experiment, the crystals of 8 (10 mg) were immersed in the aqueous solution of MO (0.1 mmol L-1) and kept in the dark. Within a short time, the light orange colored solution turned to colorless, while the colorless crystals turned to yellow. The change in the concentration of MO in the aqueous solution was monitored by UV-visible spectroscopy at various time intervals after immersing the crystals of 8 (). We note here that no further activation was needed for 8 to uptake MO compared to some of the previously reported CP-based materials.

elements.content: The exploration of dye absorption and separation using ionic MOFs or CPs with a high selectivity toward the targeted dyes become a promising research topic nowadays. The controlled separation of organic dye mixture become important during the recovery of valuable chemicals from industrial wastewater. To date, different types of promising materials such as supramolecular hydrogels, polymers, organic–inorganic hybrids, modified graphene oxide, and inorganic nanostructured materials are being explored for this purpose.

elements.content: The unique selectivity of 8 toward the anionic dye prompted us to investigate the separation study of a mixture of cationic and anionic dyes. In the present study, the mixture of cationic dye methylene blue (MB) and anionic dye methyl orange (MO) was considered for selective adsorption and separation, as they have identical molecular sizes. The immersion of 8 in the equimolar aqueous green colored solution of MB (blue colored) and MO (orange colored) resulted in a blue colored solution indicating the total adsorption of MO from the mixture (). These studies clearly indicate that 8 can selectively adsorb the anionic dyes from the solution containing a mixture of dyes.

In the present study, the mixture of cationic dye methylene blue (MB) and anionic dye methyl orange (MO) was considered for selective adsorption and separation, as they have identical molecular sizes. The immersion of 8 in the equimolar aqueous green colored solution of MB (blue colored) and MO (orange colored) resulted in a blue colored solution indicating the total adsorption of MO from the mixture (). These studies clearly indicate that 8 can selectively adsorb the anionic dyes from the solution containing a mixture of dyes.

elements.content: The amount of dye adsorbed by 8 was calculated using the following equation, q e = ( C 0 − C e m ) V where q e is the amount of MO (mg) adsorbed onto 1 g of adsorbent; C 0 and C e are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of MO in solution (mg/L); V is the volume of solution (L); and m is the mass of adsorbent (g). From this equation the calculated amount of MO that can be adsorbed by 1 g of 8 is 55.904 mg (Supporting Information) which is much higher than that of recently reported MOF {[(Cu4Cl) (CPT)4·(H2O)4]·3NO3·5NMP·3.5H2O} n , where NMP = N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (0.05 mmol g–1 or 16.37 mg g–1).

elements.content: It was shown that the complexation reactions of flexible bis-amidopyridine (L) molecule with metal ions such as Cu­(II) and Cd­(II) in the presence of nitrate, sulfate, perchlorate, thiocyanate, and hexafluorosilicate anions resulted in the formation of CPs containing versatile network geometries such as 1D-chains, 2D-layers containing (4,4)- and (6,3)-topologies, and pseudodiamondoid. The tetrahedral anions such as sulfate and perchlorate have templated the interpenetration of the networks. Interestingly, the presence of sulfate ions resulted in the triple and parallel interpenetration of 2D-layers containing (4,4)-topology in 6 as well as (6,3)-topology in 5. This interpenetration was facilitated via the formation of triple helices in both cases. While the presence of ClO4 – resulted in 2-fold parallel interpenetration of the 2D-layer containing (4,4)-topology (7) and 3-fold interpenetration of the 3D-network containing pseudodiamondoid topology (8). In all of the complexes, the anions were found to be hydrogen bonded with the amide functionalities and also interacted with the solvent molecules. Out of eight complexes, five (1, 2, and 6–8) were found to be cationic complexes as the anions do not coordinate to the metal. Among these five, complex 8 was found to uptake anionic dyes such as MO and FSD from their aqueous solutions. FSD adsorbed material (8a) was found to exhibit emission maxima in the green region. Further, 8 was shown to be useful for the separation of anionic dye MO from the mixture of aqueous solutions of MO and MB. These studies indicate 8 has a potential for purification of wastewater by removing toxic dyes. The luminescence studies indicate that the FSD adsorbed 8 has a potential for electro-optical devices.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

It was shown that the complexation reactions of flexible bis-amidopyridine (L) molecule with metal ions such as Cu(II) and Cd(II) in the presence of nitrate, sulfate, perchlorate, thiocyanate, and hexafluorosilicate anions resulted in the formation of CPs containing versatile network geometries such as 1D-chains, 2D-layers containing (4,4)- and (6,3)-topologies, and pseudodiamondoid. The tetrahedral anions such as sulfate and perchlorate have templated the interpenetration of the networks. Interestingly, the presence of sulfate ions resulted in the triple and parallel interpenetration of 2D-layers containing (4,4)-topology in 6 as well as (6,3)-topology in 5. This interpenetration was facilitated via the formation of triple helices in both cases. While the presence of ClO4 - resulted in 2-fold parallel interpenetration of the 2D-layer containing (4,4)-topology (7) and 3-fold interpenetration of the 3D-network containing pseudodiamondoid topology (8). In all of the complexes, the anions were found to be hydrogen bonded with the amide functionalities and also interacted with the solvent molecules. Out of eight complexes, five (1, 2, and 6-8) were found to be cationic complexes as the anions do not coordinate to the metal. Among these five, complex 8 was found to uptake anionic dyes such as MO and FSD from their aqueous solutions. FSD adsorbed material (8a) was found to exhibit emission maxima in the green region. Further, 8 was shown to be useful for the separation of anionic dye MO from the mixture of aqueous solutions of MO and MB. These studies indicate 8 has a potential for purification of wastewater by removing toxic dyes. The luminescence studies indicate that the FSD adsorbed 8 has a potential for electro-optical devices.

elements.content: All of the chemicals such as 3-aminopyridine, methyl orange, methylene blue, all metal salts, and solvents were purchased from local chemical suppliers; p-phenylenediacetic acid and fluorescein sodium salt were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectra were recorded with an PerkinElmerinstrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded with a Bruker D8-advance diffractometer at room temperature. The solution state absorbance spectra were recorded with the use of a Shimadzu (model no. UV-2450) UV–vis spectrophotometer. The solid state luminescence spectra were collected with a Spex Fluorolog-3 (model FL3-22) spectrofluorimeter.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All of the chemicals such as 3-aminopyridine, methyl orange, methylene blue, all metal salts, and solvents were purchased from local chemical suppliers; p-phenylenediacetic acid and fluorescein sodium salt were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. Fourier transform IR (FTIR) spectra were recorded with an PerkinElmerinstrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded with a Bruker D8-advance diffractometer at room temperature. The solution state absorbance spectra were recorded with the use of a Shimadzu (model no. UV-2450) UV-vis spectrophotometer. The solid state luminescence spectra were collected with a Spex Fluorolog-3 (model FL3-22) spectrofluorimeter.

elements.content:
Ligand L was prepared by following the earlier reported procedure.

Synthesis of Complexes <bold>1</bold>–<bold>8</bold>

Complexes 2, 3, 4, and 8 were synthesized by direct mixing: In a typical procedure, the direct mixing of the MeOH solution (5 mL) of L (0.1 mmol, 0.0346 g) with the MeOH solution (5 mL) of the metal salt (0.05 mmol) resulted in the formation of crystals of complexes 2, 3, 4, and 8 with the yields of 68%, 73%, 70%, and 76%, respectively.

Synthesis of Complexes 1-8

elements.content: Complexes 1, 5, 6, and 7 are synthesized by layering procedures: 2 mL of MeOH (1.5 mL)/H2O (0.5 mL) solvent mixture was layered carefully on to an aqueous solution (3 mL) of corresponding Cu­(II) or Cd­(II) salts (0.05 mmol). A MeOH solution (3 mL) of L (0.1 mmol, 0.0346 g) was layered on top of the above solution. After about 10 days, single crystals of complexes suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained. complex ⁡ 1 ⁡ yield : 68 % complex ⁡ 5 ⁡ yield : 70 % complex ⁡ 6 ⁡ yield : 62 % complex ⁡ 7 ⁡ yield : 66 %

elements.content: All of the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature (293 K) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located wherever possible and refined using the riding model.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

All of the single crystal data were collected on a Bruker-APEX-II CCD X-ray diffractometer that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature (293 K) by the hemisphere method. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by least-squares methods on F 2 using SHELX-2014. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The H atoms attached to the O atom or N atoms are located wherever possible and refined using the riding model.

cln_elements.content: The solid state luminescence properties of 8 and 8a have been investigated at room temperature. Complex 8 has exhibited a broad band emission in the violet region with a maximum at 410 nm at the excitation wavelength of 350 nm (). The solid state UV–visible spectrum of 8 shows a broad range absorption in the region 250–350 nm, and accordingly complex 8 was excited at 350 nm (Supporting Information). The material of L was found to be luminescence inactive with the excitation wavelengths of 280, 320, 350, or 380 nm indicating that the luminescence property of 8 did not originate from L. Therefore, it can be understood that these properties are originating from the interactions between Cd­(II) (d10) and the ligand L. For the sake of comparison, the luminescence profiles of Cu­(II) (d9) containing CPs (1, 5, and 7) were also recorded at various excited wavelengths, but they were found to be nonluminescent.

Illustrations for the crystal structures of 1 and 2: (a) 1D-zigzag chain; (b) the trapping of SiF6 2– and water molecules between 1D-zigzag chains via O–H···O, O–H···F, and N–H···F hydrogen bonds; (c) interaction involved between the chains.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Illustrations for the crystal structures of 1 and 2: (a) 1D-zigzag chain; (b) the trapping of SiF6 2- and water molecules between 1D-zigzag chains via O-H⋅⋅⋅O, O-H⋅⋅⋅F, and N-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonds; (c) interaction involved between the chains.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 3: (a) 2D-layer with (4,4)-topology containing rectangular grid; (b) offset packing mode of grid layers via hydrogen bonding and other weak interactions; (c) depiction of amide-to-amide N–H···O hydrogen bonding, face-to-face and edge-to-face aromatic interactions between the layers.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 3: (a) 2D-layer with (4,4)-topology containing rectangular grid; (b) offset packing mode of grid layers via hydrogen bonding and other weak interactions; (c) depiction of amide-to-amide N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding, face-to-face and edge-to-face aromatic interactions between the layers.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 5: (a) Herringbone network with (6,3)-topology; (b) 3-fold parallel interpenetrated herringbone networks; (c) side view of the triply interpenetrated network, the interaction involved between the interpenetrated layers: (d) space-filling mode and (e) stick mode with specific interactions indicated; (f) interaction of coordinated SO4 and H2O molecules between the triply interpenetrated layers. The ligands were shown in stick mode, and metals were shown as nodes.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 5: (a) Herringbone network with (6,3)-topology; (b) 3-fold parallel interpenetrated herringbone networks; (c) side view of the triply interpenetrated network, the interaction involved between the interpenetrated layers: (d) space-filling mode and (e) stick mode with specific interactions indicated; (f) interaction of coordinated SO4 and H2O molecules between the triply interpenetrated layers. The ligands were shown in stick mode, and metals were shown as nodes.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 6: (a) 2D-square grid network formed by Cd­(II) and L; (b) 3-fold parallel interpenetration of the 2D-square grid layers; (c) C–H···O and edge-to-face aromatic interactions among the interpenetrated layers; (d) triple helices that exist in 3-fold-interpenetrated layers; (e) SO4 2– resides in tetrahedral cavities created within the triple interpenetrated layers; (f) N–H···O hydrogen bonding between the amide and sulfate ion.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 6: (a) 2D-square grid network formed by Cd(II) and L; (b) 3-fold parallel interpenetration of the 2D-square grid layers; (c) C-H⋅⋅⋅O and edge-to-face aromatic interactions among the interpenetrated layers; (d) triple helices that exist in 3-fold-interpenetrated layers; (e) SO4 2- resides in tetrahedral cavities created within the triple interpenetrated layers; (f) N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding between the amide and sulfate ion.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 7: (a) 2D-layer of (4,4)-topology with unusual brick wall geometry; (b) 2-fold parallel interpenetration of the layers and inclusion of ClO4 – and H2O in cavities; (c) β-sheet hydrogen bonding among the interpenetrated layers; (d) a 2D-layer formed with ClO4 – ion and H2O molecules by hydrogen bonding interaction; (e) double helices within the 2-fold-interpenetrated layers.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 7: (a) 2D-layer of (4,4)-topology with unusual brick wall geometry; (b) 2-fold parallel interpenetration of the layers and inclusion of ClO4 - and H2O in cavities; (c) β-sheet hydrogen bonding among the interpenetrated layers; (d) a 2D-layer formed with ClO4 - ion and H2O molecules by hydrogen bonding interaction; (e) double helices within the 2-fold-interpenetrated layers.

cln_elements.content: Illustrations for the crystal structure of 8: (a) 3D-pseudodiamondoid network [the Cd­(II) nodes, which are being connected by the L molecules, are joined together by thick bonds for the sake of clarity]; (b) distorted-diamondoid network; (c) CdN4 unit; (d) amide-to-amide N–H···O hydrogen bonding and π–π aromatic interactions among the interpenetrated networks; (e) 3-fold interpenetration of the pseudodiamondoid network.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Illustrations for the crystal structure of 8: (a) 3D-pseudodiamondoid network [the Cd(II) nodes, which are being connected by the L molecules, are joined together by thick bonds for the sake of clarity]; (b) distorted-diamondoid network; (c) CdN4 unit; (d) amide-to-amide N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding and π-π aromatic interactions among the interpenetrated networks; (e) 3-fold interpenetration of the pseudodiamondoid network.
